repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Component E Under Privatization
            and Utility Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Component E Under Privatization and
            Utility Sector Reform Project for Uganda had a satisfactory
            outcome with modest risk to development outcome. Performance
            by the Bank and the borrower was satisfactory as well. The
            report outlines nine lessons learned from the project and
            are as follows: (1) If properly structured, it is possible
            to successfully implement a private sector project that
            brings private capital, private sector efficiencies, and
            first rated investors into an underdeveloped power
            distribution and reap substantial economic benefits for the
            country and the sector. (2) Loss reduction in chronically
            poorly managed utilities is very challenging and takes
            significant time and effort to tackle it, particularly in
            countries with limited capacity. (3) PPP/Concessions are
            long-term arrangements that need flexibility and commitment
            from all involved parties to be able to adjust to unforeseen
            circumstances, remain in place, and being successful. (4)
            There is a fine balance to be struck between reducing the
            perceived risks for the private sector and creating the
            incentives to tackle sector issues. (5) Low income countries
            may need donor funding to facilitate faster increase in
            access than private financing can bring. (6) The commercial
            mindset of the public entities is critical to ensure the
            long-term sustainability of the sector performance
            improvement. (7) Projects supporting Public Private
            Partnerships in power distribution required active
            supervision to ensure timely resolution of emerging issues
            before they start to negatively affect the project. (8)
            Designing the IDA support as a credit restructuring was
            innovative, cost-effective, and, more importantly,
            responsive to Government of Ugandas (GoU) needs. (9) The
            innovative approach, however, became a burden during
            supervision as the Banks processes and systems were not
            prepared to handle the innovative aspects of it.

13973694.theme: Regulation and competition policy,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Privatization and Utility Sector
            Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Uganda - Privatization and
            Utility Sector Reform Project were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: A proper legal environment is essential for forcing
            procedural discipline in privatization transactions. The
            monitoring and evaluation system was well developed and
            therefore was effective in tracking implementation progress.
            The environmental assessments and decommissioning plans led
            to unexpected results which were beyond the scope of the
            project. Although there was a full time coordinator for the
            environmental subcomponent, NEMA has indicated that the
            presence of an environmental specialist in the PU would have
            improved communication between them considerably and perhaps
            more could have been achieved. Policy consensus is essential
            before major reform programs are implemented to ensure
            success and minimize reversals. Not overselling the benefits
            of privatization and openly addressing the inevitable
            negative aspects helps dissipate fears and create realistic
            expectations among the public.
